quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Karri and his team are building their company and their product in a really unique way with a huge focus on craft and quality, no AB tests, no metrics-based goals, instead a focus on taste and opinions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian product-building philosophy that prioritizes craft and strong opinions over experimentation and metric targets.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, no durable cross-functional teams, instead teams assemble around a project and then disperse once it's done.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An alternative org design model that emphasizes project-based team formation rather than long-lived squads.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, they have just one product manager as the head of product and that's it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A provocative staffing choice that challenges the conventional assumption that scaling requires many PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We talk about something called the linear method of building product, which is big on building opinionated software, working in consistent cycles amongst other principles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a named methodology that suggests repeatable operating principles for building product.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also get into Linear's unique hiring approach, which involves a paid work trial where candidates work alongside the team for a number of days instead of just having an interview,
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical hiring tactic that replaces interviews with paid, real-world collaboration to assess fit and skill.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I moved cash over from another bank and it literally took less than half an hour to set up the account and wire money over at no cost.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of reducing operational friction in a core workflow (switching banks) with a specific time and cost outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They make you want to use the site more often, which I've never felt with another banking site.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable product insight: great UX can turn a utilitarian task into something users voluntarily engage with more frequently.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Algorithmic trading has historically been reserved for the hedge fund elite.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Frames the market shift and opportunity: tools are democratizing capabilities once limited to specialized institutions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Composer is the first ever algorithmic trading platform where you don't need any coding experience and includes a full range of trading indicators for you to get creative and a Discord community of 2,500 traders to discuss your ideas with.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology for adoption—lower the skill barrier (no-code) and pair it with community for iteration and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With $1 billion in trading volume and over 1 million trades executed, Composer already has many big-time investors using the platform regularly.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides credibility via specific traction metrics that practitioners can use as a benchmark for platform maturity and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: What Linear is and why it exists
quotes.text: What we saw often is that the tools available for managing software projects weren't really cutting it.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A clear problem statement rooted in repeated firsthand experience across multiple companies—useful as a bar for when to build a new product/tool.

quotes.topic_title: What Linear is and why it exists
quotes.text: I think a lot of them felt very clunky or complex or just like they had this legacy way of thinking about software development.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode (legacy assumptions) that practitioners can watch for when evaluating or designing internal tools.

quotes.topic_title: What Linear is and why it exists
quotes.text: With Linear, we set out to build this most frictionless and streamlined system for modern software development.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A crisp product principle (“frictionless and streamlined”) that can guide prioritization and tradeoffs in product development.

quotes.topic_title: What Linear is and why it exists
quotes.text: I'm also happy to share that we've been profitable the last two years.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A concrete business outcome that signals an alternative path to growth beyond prolonged burn.

quotes.topic_title: What Linear is and why it exists
quotes.text: We also have this thing where we actually have this net negative lifetime burn rate, which means that we just have more cash in the bank today than we have raised.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive metric and definition that challenges the default startup narrative of spending raised capital to grow.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for craft without perfection paralysis
quotes.text: We actually believe that when you start building the thing you actually start realizing more how it should work and how it should be better.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A build-first learning model: implementation reveals product truth faster than extended upfront design.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for craft without perfection paralysis
quotes.text: A lot of times with the teams we tell them, "Just put it there in, I don't know, the first week almost. After you have some designs in place or some design ideas, just put it into the app and ship it to production." It's only visible to us so we internally can test it out.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for avoiding perfection paralysis: ship to production early behind internal visibility for rapid iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for craft without perfection paralysis
quotes.text: In those stages, the experience can be a little janky or it's not that polished, but we're okay with it because we are saying, "It's not finished. We just want to get your feedback early so we can make it better." Once we get to the full general release, then we pay more attention to the actual polish or the craft.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A staged release framework that preserves craft by delaying polish until after early feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for craft without perfection paralysis
quotes.text: I think sometimes people think that craft is about perfecting things and perfecting them in a very organized way or very early on. The downside with this perfection mindset is that it can be sometimes hard to put anything out because nothing is ever fully perfect.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing: “craft” isn’t early perfection—over-indexing on it can block shipping entirely.

quotes.topic_title: Creating space for craft without perfection paralysis
quotes.text: We try to balance this thinking with the fact that we should be always pushing things out very quickly, but then also fixing them, improving them very quickly.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical operating principle: speed and craft can coexist if iteration cycles are fast on both shipping and refinement.

quotes.topic_title: Why Linear has almost no PMs
quotes.text: I think with the craft it always starts with people need to care about it. If it's not valued in the company, then it's very hard for anyone to do because people don't feel like it's valued.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A culture-first model: craft/quality emerges only when the organization explicitly values it, not just when individuals try hard.

quotes.topic_title: Why Linear has almost no PMs
quotes.text: You need to align on it. It's like you cannot run a company with multiple different kinds of cultures.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical warning for founding teams: misaligned quality/shipping cultures create execution friction that process can’t fix.

quotes.topic_title: Why Linear has almost no PMs
quotes.text: One of the things I think that happens is when you build a team and you start creating these very specific roles for everything I think that often the PM can be the ones figuring things out and making decisions and guiding the team, but they're not the ones building the feature. They're not there looking at it the whole day like where does this button go or how does it work?
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of specialized roles: separating decision-making from building can degrade craft because builders see the details all day.

quotes.topic_title: Why Linear has almost no PMs
quotes.text: I think a lot of that, this craft for us happens when we give the project team this ownership and the project team is just engineering and design.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A concrete operating model: end-to-end ownership sits with engineering+design rather than a PM-led structure.

quotes.topic_title: Why Linear has almost no PMs
quotes.text: He figured out a way to create those safe areas that are dynamic based on the sub-menu positioning and everything.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A specific example of ownership-driven craft: an engineer proactively improves UX interaction details without being told.

quotes.topic_title: The role of Linear’s head of product
quotes.text: We started to see that we have enough features and areas of the product and also the team speaker that it's hard to keep aligned on all of these things or even keep track of things.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical trigger for adding product leadership: complexity and alignment overhead become the bottleneck as features and teams grow.

quotes.topic_title: The role of Linear’s head of product
quotes.text: For us founders, we realized none of us, we are not super experienced in data tools. We need someone to help out.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Highlights a clear hiring heuristic: bring in expertise when founders lack depth in a critical domain.

quotes.topic_title: The role of Linear’s head of product
quotes.text: I think there's different ways of doing that. I think always the easiest way is let's just copy what some other company is doing, but we didn't want to do that.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A contrarian stance against defaulting to competitive copying, emphasizing intentional product definition.

quotes.topic_title: The role of Linear’s head of product
quotes.text: We wanted to figure out what is actually a useful way to use this data or get this data?
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Frames product discovery around real utility rather than feature parity—especially for analytics/insights tooling.

quotes.topic_title: The role of Linear’s head of product
quotes.text: To us, it's more like he figures out the direction of the product and steers some of the efforts and not like he's there in every meeting and making every decision or writing every spec or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Defines a higher-leverage PM/Head of Product model focused on direction-setting and alignment over spec-writing and meeting attendance.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without PMs: requirements and trade-offs
quotes.text: I think sometimes when companies specialize roles a lot it's because it's more efficient. If the engineer spends 100% of their time coding something, then it's like they're using their skillset to the max. Then, we just think that in order to build quality things or build things in a certain way it's actually better if people actually also spend some time thinking about things and not just executing.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A clear trade-off model: specialization maximizes efficiency, but allocating time for “thinking” across builders can improve product quality.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without PMs: requirements and trade-offs
quotes.text: Yes, for every project there's a project lead. That lead can be engineer or designer. It's not a formal role or it's not based on your whatever level or it's just like you need to be certain title that you can be that. It's more like an assignment that now you are responsible getting the project started and working together with the team, figuring it out, and then communicating changes or communicating how that progress happens.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A lightweight operating mechanism for PM-light orgs: rotate “project lead” ownership to ensure coordination and communication still happen.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without PMs: requirements and trade-offs
quotes.text: Also, not everyone wants to do that, which is fine, but we on the hiring front try to hire people that are interested in the broader scope than just the specific skillset that they have.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical hiring filter for PM-less teams: prioritize candidates who want broader ownership beyond their functional craft.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without PMs: requirements and trade-offs
quotes.text: Basically, you cannot really interview engineers only for the engineering skills. You also have to interview them for the product skills.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Actionable hiring guidance: if engineers will absorb PM responsibilities, product thinking must be explicitly assessed in interviews.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without PMs: requirements and trade-offs
quotes.text: We just look for does this person have opinions about products and how they work? Can they form opinions and can they use their own judgment at times? Then, can they communicate or articulate those things as well?
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A concrete evaluation rubric for PM-light hiring: opinions + judgment + articulation as proxies for product capability.

quotes.topic_title: When design is a real competitive differentiator
quotes.text: My belief is that any domain or industry, the more it matters, the more the design matters.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for prioritizing design investment based on the stakes and importance of the domain.

quotes.topic_title: When design is a real competitive differentiator
quotes.text: But then as you build the hundreds, thousand different email clients, any email client now has to be pretty good to be even considered an email client. The bar is so high.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Explains why design becomes a competitive differentiator as categories mature and options proliferate.

quotes.topic_title: When design is a real competitive differentiator
quotes.text: So I think the design is, it's almost like a very basic thing now, that from pretty much from the very beginning you need pretty high level design for people to even pay attention or consider you seriously.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that “good enough” design is now table stakes even at launch, not a later-stage polish.

quotes.topic_title: When design is a real competitive differentiator
quotes.text: But I would also say design is never going to be the reason why a company is successful. It's like the company still has to have some other things. The product still needs to be something, it needs to be better in some ways or it needs to be different in some ways.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A counterbalance to design-led thinking: design amplifies real value but can’t substitute for it.

quotes.topic_title: When design is a real competitive differentiator
quotes.text: It's like even before you use the product, you start thinking that this is a high quality product and I'm going to love it.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Highlights how design/brand cues (e.g., packaging/landing pages) set expectations that influence adoption and perception.

quotes.topic_title: Building an authentic brand over time
quotes.text: To me, I think the brand should be always authentic and it should, I think even if people can't articulate it, if people start to feel like something is off, I think there can be companies or startups, they think about brands like, oh brand is the logo or the colors of the website or something.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Reframes brand from visual identity to authenticity that customers can sense even if they can’t explain it.

quotes.topic_title: Building an authentic brand over time
quotes.text: But you actually didn't think about what's your brand, what is the message or voice you want to talk about? And it doesn't also, the brand doesn't happen overnight.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to define message/voice explicitly and treat brand as a long-term compounding asset.

quotes.topic_title: Building an authentic brand over time
quotes.text: So it's basically just you start in the beginning and when you start a company you don't have no brand and so you have to create it and you create it over time by the things you do, the things you say, how you say them and how do you approach things, how do you treat customers, how do you build the website or the product?
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Provides a practical “inputs list” for brand-building: behavior, communication, customer treatment, and product/website quality.

quotes.topic_title: Building an authentic brand over time
quotes.text: And I don't know how many hours or meetings or conversations there was about the brand and the brand was always, it's part of everything the company does.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Illustrates (via Airbnb) that strong brands are operationalized through continuous attention, not a one-time exercise.

quotes.topic_title: Building an authentic brand over time
quotes.text: So that's the power of the brand, people stop thinking about the other things or they start understanding, okay, this is the thing for this.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Captures the outcome of brand strength: category association that reduces consideration of alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear reviews design and decides it’s done
quotes.text: And then what happens sometimes, it's in the initial stages, obviously we're not going to start fixing everything, it's just more like let's try to get the main concept there and figure out how it works.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical review heuristic: early reviews focus on validating the core concept rather than polishing details.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear reviews design and decides it’s done
quotes.text: But then before we are launching it, I might just go in and try it out and try the different states and click it around.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Sets a hands-on quality bar where the decision-maker personally exercises edge cases before release.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear reviews design and decides it’s done
quotes.text: And sometimes I find things, like we were building this threading to comments and then when it looked all good in the demos and stuff, and then I went to try it and try different lengths of messages and stuff and then I start to see, oh, sometimes the animations are kind of janky or it's just off.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Concrete example of why “try it yourself” catches issues demos miss (realistic content + interaction reveals quality gaps).

quotes.topic_title: How Linear reviews design and decides it’s done
quotes.text: Yeah, I would say a lot of things that we do is more like that but we don't do AP testing or we don't do specific, go follow certain metrics or something.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A contrarian stance: release decisions are driven more by judgment and product feel than formal experiments or metric targets.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear reviews design and decides it’s done
quotes.text: So I think that there isn't specific review stages. It's more like, yeah, let's check on this project every week or every two weeks and then before releasing, let's also make a review of it and really test it out, is it the quality we want?
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Describes a lightweight cadence-based review process instead of rigid phase gates, with a final quality-focused pre-release pass.

quotes.topic_title: The Linear Method: opinionated software
quotes.text: I personally have this belief that productivity software should be, and especially company software should be opinionated.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A clear principle that sets a product strategy direction: prioritize strong defaults over flexibility for internal/team tools.

quotes.topic_title: The Linear Method: opinionated software
quotes.text: But what happens is people start spending a lot of time figuring things out. Like, how does this feature work? You can use it in 10 different ways and then every team or everyone figures out the different way of doing it.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of “flexible” software: it can create process divergence and waste time across teams.

quotes.topic_title: The Linear Method: opinionated software
quotes.text: So our thinking is we like to provide this good default or good opinions. Like, this is how the feature works and this is how the workflow works. So you, as a user or as a team don't have to think about it and you can focus on the work you do.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for product design: encode the workflow into defaults to reduce cognitive overhead and keep users focused on outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: The Linear Method: opinionated software
quotes.text: And the other thing is, my design mantra is always design something for someone. It is very hard to design everything for everyone because you just end up with a very generalized solution.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A memorable targeting heuristic: optimize for a specific user to avoid bland, lowest-common-denominator product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: The Linear Method: opinionated software
quotes.text: So being opinionated, I think the value it provides people is you don't have to think too much or spend more time on the tool than you do on your actual work.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical success metric for productivity tools: minimize time spent “using the tool” relative to doing real work.

quotes.topic_title: Cycles: focus mechanism similar to sprints
quotes.text: But basically, I think why we created cycles is that I think any team that works on software or some other products, you always have almost infinite list of things to do and that list gets longer every day.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Frames cycles as a practical response to the reality of ever-growing backlogs, motivating a structured focus mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Cycles: focus mechanism similar to sprints
quotes.text: So the cycles is just a way to say that for the next week or the next two weeks or whatever timeframe, we are going to work on these things and these other things we think are the priority or the focus for this timeframe.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Defines cycles as a lightweight commitment device that forces explicit prioritization over a fixed timebox.

quotes.topic_title: Cycles: focus mechanism similar to sprints
quotes.text: So you have an answer when someone comes to you to ask, "Why didn't you do this other thing before?" Then you can say, "Well, we did decide to do that, but then something happened and we had to do this other thing."
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Highlights how cycles create an auditable baseline decision, making priority changes clearer and easier to communicate.

quotes.topic_title: Cycles: focus mechanism similar to sprints
quotes.text: So the cycles, it's very similar to sprints, but we like to call it cycles because we are not really sprinting anywhere.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional “sprint” framing by emphasizing sustainable cadence over speed-for-speed’s-sake.

quotes.topic_title: Cycles: focus mechanism similar to sprints
quotes.text: And so it's just meant to help the team to focus on, let's just focus on this few things and forget about the infinite list of other things that are in the background.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Actionable focus principle: intentionally ignore the backlog noise to reduce distraction and increase throughput on priorities.

quotes.topic_title: No feature-level metrics: intuition plus customer closeness
quotes.text: But in terms of specific features, we don't have goals for those.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A clear, contrarian stance against feature-level metric targets that many product teams default to.

quotes.topic_title: No feature-level metrics: intuition plus customer closeness
quotes.text: It's more like we want to solve this problem. And ideally, the success what it looks like customers agree that the problem is solved or they enjoy the solution and it's not like that the metrics went up.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Defines a customer-validated definition of success that prioritizes problem-solving over metric movement.

quotes.topic_title: No feature-level metrics: intuition plus customer closeness
quotes.text: We like to talk about this internally, I like this mixture of magic and science and how we described, there's always some level of science that we do.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework for balancing qualitative rigor with informed judgment.

quotes.topic_title: No feature-level metrics: intuition plus customer closeness
quotes.text: But usually we have some kind of question we want to answer. It's like, I wonder what is going on. And then we look at it versus let's pull some metrics and then decide that we should increase this metric.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: A practical methodology for using data diagnostically (question-led) rather than as a goal-setting engine (metric-led).

quotes.topic_title: No feature-level metrics: intuition plus customer closeness
quotes.text: I think sometimes people use data a lot or too much because they're worrying or they're afraid that, will I make the wrong choice? And I'm using data to make the choice for me.
quotes.speaker: Karri Saarinen
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that more data always improves decisions, reframing it as a way to avoid accountability.
